Born and raised in Hawaii, and a graduate of Punahou School, he brings nearly 20 years of experience in nonprofit executive leadership. Trevor started his journey in New York City working for Broadway Dance Center. Other positions include: Chief Advancement Officer of The Diller-Quaile School of Music; Deputy Director of Saratoga International Theater Institute; and Deputy/Program Director for The Drama League of New York. Trevor is a member of the Association of Fundraising Professionals and is a Certified Fund Raising Executive (CFRE). He holds a degree in Theatre Arts from University of Miami, a Master of Business Administration degree from Pace University, and a Master of Science degree in Nonprofit Management from Columbia University. John Rampage, Artistic Director John Rampage is a performer, actor, choreographer, and director who has served as Diamond Head Theatre‚Äôs Artistic Director since 1995. He is the creative mastermind behind all of the theatre‚Äôs productions and programs, overseeing the curation of two or more shows each season and selects directors, musical directors, and set designers. His relationship with the theatre began in 1975 where he performed as Tommy Gilas in the 1975 production of Music Man. In the 1980s, Rampage danced and sang his way across the U.S. and Europe and returned in 1991 as choreographer of Evita. More than 120 productions have been shared with the community under his oversight. A 47-time Po‚Äòokela Award winner for excellence in the theatre, John is also the recipient of the Hawaii State Theatre Council 2006 Pierre Bowman Award. Claim Your Listing CAMPER SUMMARY PRESENTED BY Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort, near Mayo, Florida, is a lively campground that caters to a variety of camping styles, from tent setups to RVs and even cozy cabins. With its year-round availability, it‚Äôs a great spot for those looking to escape into nature while enjoying some modern comforts. The campground boasts a heated pool, hot tub, and a private spring, making it a hit for families and friends alike. Visitors rave about the friendly staff and the clean facilities, including well-kept bathrooms and showers. One camper noted, ‚ÄúThe staff are very friendly and helpful, the grounds are kept clean,‚Äù which really captures the welcoming vibe here. For outdoor enthusiasts, the Suwannee River offers fantastic opportunities for kayaking, tubing, and fishing. Many guests enjoyed the riverfront area, which provides a more rustic charm compared to the standard RV park. As one reviewer put it, ‚ÄúWe stayed in the river front area which was a bit more feral than the RV park but offers more charm & shade.‚Äù With plenty of activities on-site, including a playground and organized events, there‚Äôs never a dull moment. Whether you‚Äôre looking to relax by the water or dive into some fun family activities, Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort has got you covered. Read More Suggest an Edit Location Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort is located in Florida Directions Traveling East and West I-10; Exit 283 Live Oak, Jasper. Take South 129 through Live Oak to Hwy 51 and turn right. Follow the Hwy 51 signs around the round-about. Go south on Hwy 51 over the Suwannee River. Take a left on County Rd 354 for about 3.5 m iles. A sign for the Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort and Campground and Convict Spirngs will be on the right. Turn left on Primrose Rd .8 miles to the resort. Lot to do (spring, river, playground, pool, spa, etc.). Fair price. Would stay again. Site 55 Month of Visit March Share Report S Samantha B. The staff are very friendly and helpful, the grounds are kept clean, the bathrooms are nice. We did the primitive camping no power no electric, but they have spaces with it and RV sites, the primitive sections just have more privacy than those. My sites didn‚Äôt have great level spots for a tent but it was right next to the spring and close to the river for fishing which is why we came. Hubs caught a catfish on his birthday- it was a great time. They have a heated pool and are expanding. Site p14 and p15 Month of Visit February Share Report Aspen H. Their lodge and resturaunt is cute. Their employees are friendly. They have a spring too and we camped right on the river. Site primitive 12 Month of Visit November Share Report Amanda W. Food is good on the weekends, live music, very poor wifi. Spots by the dog park don‚Äôt have shade but most of the other sites do. Lots of fun activities. Great bike path just off property. Friendly staff. Site 212 was 50 amp only so I had to use a converter. Can rent kayaks on site if you don‚Äôt own one. Site 212 Month of Visit September (8) View All Share Report Amy M. We did the 6 mile kayak trip and stopped at 3 springs which was AWESOME.  Restaurant wasn‚Äôt open when we were there, but they have a small shop for essentials. Can‚Äôt wait to go back. 5 üåü Site 189 Month of Visit September Share Report Carol N. If you like activities there are plenty. Anything from kayaking and bike riding to pigeon races and fishing. A lot of the tent sites are along the Suwannee River. Great views! My only complaint is it can use some updating. But they are trying!ÔøºÔøº Site 3 Month of Visit January Share Report Richard B. Guide Reviewed Mar. 21, 2021 Great family park. Clean individual bathrooms. Pool area is nice. High water has the spring covered up so can't comment on that. Playground for the kids. Wifi all over the park. Booked a second stay while on the property. Share Report Chelsea C. Traveler Reviewed Dec. 21, 2020 Quirky and active riverside RV community SRRR is a 40 acre park with country-clever DIY vibes and unusual artifacts including a handmade automated bowling alley in an abandoned chicken coop with mechanical levers that return balls and reset pins, weekly events ranging from chicken shit bingo to pigeon racing, a dog park, and a cozy spring-side divey lodge-like restaurant. Despite its name, convict spring is a beautiful clear fresh water spring, best appreciated in winter when no kids are kicking up dirt in it. I have tent-camped in a lovely prim spot beside the river and also RV camped with my Skoolie here. I adore the beauty of the location, spring-side on the broad Suwannee River, but had to subtract one star for the horrendously bad and unwelcoming (verging on foreboding) service at the cafe, and disappointment that the hot tub was closed both times we visited. Will def return to this spot. (5) View All Share Report T Tina S. Guide Reviewed Aug. 2, 2020 Fun campground We stayed at site 105 (full hook-up, $45 per night) and it was perfect üëå  Neighbors only on one side, close to pool and a short walk to Convict Spring. Catch & release pond for fishing is also super close. Friday night bingo and Saturday has pigeon races, chicken poo üí©  bingo and trivia/karaoke.   You can rent kayaks or canoes to take up the Suwannee River. Very dog üêï  friendly; our Goldens loved swimming in Convict Springs. We will definitely be back!! Share Report Rosina E. Guide Reviewed Jul. 19, 2020 Meh So this is the redneck riviera and there are tons of kids, Trump and confederate flags, and flies, plus the twice a day cow paddy smell. The roads are narrow and water diveted going down to the river, the springs smells like tadpoles, and the kayak launch was a diveted dirt road that looks real sad. For this price in the middle of nowhere, the WiFi sucks and the water pressure is often like 5 psi. We didn‚Äôt use any facilities but absolutely NO ONE was social distancing in the office, pool or really anywhere. Won‚Äôt be back. Share Report E Emily A. Guide Reviewed Apr. 25, 2020 Wish I could give this place 10 stars Just visited for our first time this week. It is absolutely our favorite campground of all now. The lower section has dispersed tent camping right on the river underneath beautiful big oak trees. Couldn‚Äôt even imagine a better campsite! They‚Äôll take you pretty much anywhere you want on the river so you can kayak or canoe and visit the variety of natural springs in the area. Our second night ended up being pretty scary with tornado warnings but the staff came down to get us and opened up the lodge after hours for us to shelter in during the storm. Honestly I couldn‚Äôt imagine a better campground. Share Report Gary M. Scout Reviewed Apr. 21, 2020 Expensive but nice Upper is spacious, bath house has no air conditioning which is BAD in summer. Folks are real friendly and staff is great. Share Report R Rick & Rene Scout Reviewed Sep. 18, 2019 Unique This is my husband and my second stay here.  The town of Mayo is a  small quite town so it is advisable to have your provisions, as it is approximately 45 minutes to most shopping.  The upper level sites are spacious and clean with the lower level more rustic. We love the restaurant, the spring, the entertainment, and the unique.....to say the least, weekend games/activities. EVERYTHING  is dog friendly.  That is a big plus for us as our westie dog Mojo goes everywhere with us. We come here to "get away from it all" and chillax. Share Report Gabriel M. Scout Reviewed May. 10, 2018 Suwanee River RIGHT ON!!! This is a really family friendly campground. We try and go 4-5 times a year and each time NEVER disappoints. It not only sits on Convict Springs, but on the Suwanee River as well. In addition to having chicken poop bingo and pigeon races (yes, those are real things! LOL) They also have regular bingo, karaoke and live music. There are RV spots, tent camping, hotel rooms, motel rooms, cabins and houses. Camping at Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort can cost between $30.00 and $70.00 depending on the site. Does Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort have RV hookups? According to TheDyrt.com, Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort has 30 amp and 50 amp electric hookups, water hookups and sewer hookups. Are fires allowed at Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort? Yes, according to campers on TheDyrt.com, fires are allowed at Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort, although make sure to check current fire restrictions in the area. Does Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort have wifi? Yes, according to campers on TheDyrt.com, Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort does have wifi. Is there cell phone reception at Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort? According to campers on TheDyrt.com, there is no coverage for AT&T, some coverage for T-Mobile, and some coverage for Verizon. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned camper or new to the experience, there are certain items you‚Äôll want to be sure to pack. From the practical to the comforts of home, these 10 essentials will help ensure your camping trip is a success. 1. Sturdy Tent The foundation of your camping setup, your tent needs to be able to withstand the elements. Look for a high-quality, weatherproof tent that‚Äôs easy to assemble and has enough space for you and your gear. 2. Sleeping Bag and Pad Staying warm and comfortable at night is key. Pack a reliable sleeping bag rated for the expected temperatures, and don‚Äôt forget a sleeping pad to insulate you from the cold ground. 3. Camp Stove and Fuel Unless you plan to cook over an open fire, a portable camp stove is a must-have for preparing meals. Choose one that‚Äôs compact and easy to use, and be sure to bring enough fuel canisters. 4. Headlamps or Flashlights Illumination is crucial when the sun goes down. Pack multiple headlamps or flashlights, and don‚Äôt forget extra batteries. 5. Cooler and Ice Packs Keep perishable foods and drinks cool with a durable cooler and plenty of ice packs. This will help ensure you have access to cold snacks and beverages throughout your trip. 6. Multi-Tool or Pocket Knife A versatile multi-tool or pocket knife is handy for all sorts of tasks, from cutting rope to repairing equipment. 7. First Aid Kit Be prepared for minor injuries and accidents with a well-stocked first aid kit. Include bandages, antiseptic, pain relievers, and any personal medications you may need. 8. Waterproof Matches or Lighter Whether you‚Äôre starting a campfire or needing to light a camp stove, having a reliable way to produce a flame is essential. Pack waterproof matches or a lighter to ensure you can get a fire going, even in damp conditions. 9. Camp Chairs After a long day of hiking or exploring, you‚Äôll appreciate having comfortable camp chairs to relax in around the fire pit or picnic table. 10. Portable Power Bank Keep your devices charged with a reliable portable power bank. This will allow you to stay connected, use your GPS, and capture memories throughout your camping adventure. Remember, the specific items you‚Äôll need may vary depending on the length of your trip, the weather conditions, and the activities you have planned. But this list covers the tent camping essentials that should be at the top of your packing list. Happy camping! No Comments filed under: River Lore Relaxing Camping on the Suwannee River in Florida Posted September 10, 2024 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort The Suwannee River: A Tranquil Haven for Nature Lovers and Outdoor Enthusiasts Nestled in the heart of Florida, the Suwannee River stands as a tranquil haven for nature lovers and outdoor enthusiasts alike. With its pristine waters, lush surroundings, and abundance of wildlife, the Suwannee River offers a peaceful retreat that beckons to those seeking a respite from the hustle and bustle of daily life. Flowing for 246 miles through the scenic landscapes of Florida, the Suwannee River provides ample opportunities for outdoor activities such as kayaking, canoeing, fishing, and birdwatching. As visitors paddle along the gentle currents of the river, they are greeted by the soothing symphony of nature, with the calls of birds and the rustle of the wind through the trees creating a serene soundtrack for their journey. One of the most beloved aspects of the Suwannee River is its abundant wildlife. From graceful wading birds and playful otters to majestic manatees and elusive deer, the river and its surrounding forests are teeming with diverse species, offering nature enthusiasts the chance to observe and appreciate the wonders of the natural world. For those who prefer to keep their feet on solid ground, the Suwannee River Wilderness Trail presents a network of trails that wind through unspoiled woodlands and showcase the region‚Äôs breathtaking beauty. Hikers and nature lovers can embark on an adventure through dense forests, past crystal-clear springs, and alongside the river‚Äôs banks, immersing themselves in the tranquil ambiance of this natural paradise. Campers also find solace along the Suwannee River, as the area offers numerous campgrounds and recreational areas where they can pitch a tent, build a campfire, and fall asleep under a blanket of stars, serenaded by the gentle lullaby of the river. In addition to its natural allure, the Suwannee River holds historical significance, with landmarks and sites that hark back to a bygone era, adding a layer of depth and intrigue to this idyllic retreat. As a testament to its timeless appeal, the Suwannee River continues to captivate and inspire all who encounter its beauty, making it an enduring favorite for nature lovers and outdoor enthusiasts seeking a peaceful escape in the embrace of nature‚Äôs splendor. Whether one is drawn to its serene waters, verdant landscapes, or abundant wildlife, the Suwannee River stands as an inviting sanctuary that beckons all to experience its tranquil embrace. View from the river rooms No Comments filed under: River Lore Suwannee River Rendezvous Posted August 10, 2024 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort Suwannee River Rendezvous is a fantastic destination for camping in North Florida. In conclusion, camping at Suwannee River Rendezvous in North Florida is an enriching and enjoyable experience for anyone seeking a retreat into nature. Whether it‚Äôs the tranquil beauty of the river, the diverse outdoor activities, or the welcoming campground facilities, this destination has something to offer for every camper. No Comments filed under: River Lore Backing a camper into a back-in site at Suwannee River Rendezvous Posted July 20, 2024 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort Backing a camper into a back-in site at Suwannee River Rendezvous can be an intimidating experience for many campers, especially those new to RVing. However, with a few tips and some practice, it can become a manageable task. First, before arriving at the campground, it‚Äôs important to familiarize yourself with the layout of the site. Knowing the position of hookups, trees, and potential obstacles can make the backing-in process much smoother. Upon arrival, take a few minutes to survey the site and plan your approach. When it comes time to back in, having a spotter outside the vehicle can be incredibly helpful. Clear and concise hand signals can aid in guiding the driver, ensuring that the camper is positioned accurately. Communication between the driver and the spotter is key, so establishing a set of signals or using walkie-talkies can help streamline the process. Remember to take it slow. Maneuvering a camper into a tight spot requires patience and precision. Utilize your mirrors and take small, deliberate movements to avoid oversteering. If necessary, don‚Äôt hesitate to pull forward and readjust your angle before continuing. It‚Äôs also crucial to remain mindful of your surroundings. Keep an eye on potential hazards around your campsite and be aware of neighboring campers and their vehicles. Being respectful of others‚Äô space and property is a fundamental aspect of the camping community. Finally, don‚Äôt be afraid to ask for help if needed. Many campgrounds, including Suwannee River Rendezvous, have friendly staff and fellow campers who are more than willing to offer guidance and assistance. Embracing the camaraderie of the camping experience can turn what may seem like a daunting task into a bonding opportunity with fellow enthusiasts. In conclusion, backing a camper into a back-in site at Suwannee River Rendezvous may pose a challenge, but with preparation, clear communication, and a patient approach, it can be a rewarding and successful endeavor. Happy camping! No Comments filed under: River Lore Primitive Camping on the Suwannee Posted June 15, 2024 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort Primitive camping on the Suwannee River offers an immersive outdoor experience in the heart of nature. As the sun sets behind the cypress trees and the river‚Äôs gentle current serenades the surroundings, the tranquility of primitive camping becomes evident. Whether setting up camp on the riverbanks or under the shade of ancient oaks, the sense of disconnection from modern life is immediate. Connect with the environment The absence of modern facilities and amenities is a pivotal aspect of primitive camping. Pitching a tent, building a campfire, and cooking over open flames harken back to a simpler time, allowing campers to truly connect with the environment. The crackling of the fire and the sounds of nocturnal wildlife create an atmosphere that is both humbling and captivating. Stars and more stars The Suwannee River‚Äôs primitive camping sites provide an unobstructed view of the star-studded night sky, free from the light pollution of urban areas. Gazing up at the constellations while nestled in the wilderness is a remarkable experience that fosters introspection and appreciation for the natural world. Terms & Conditions - Suwannee River Rendezvous Skip to Content Navigate Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort & Campground - 828 N.E. Primrose Rd, Mayo FL 32066 Phone : 386-294-2510 Email : frontdesk@suwanneeriverrendezvous.com BOOK NOW Home Site Map RV Resort Camping Lodging The A-Frame House The Chalet House Hill Top Rooms Lodge Rooms Log Cabins River Rooms The Spring House The Suite The Tree House Things to Do Coloring Pages Scavenger Hunt Pickle Ball Complex Activities Calendar Canoe and Kayak Rentals & Trips Park Activities Fishing & Hunting Special Events Out & About Cookin‚Äô Shack Information About Us Personal Pet Pens Area Springs Terms & Conditions The Suwannee River Convict Spring News Contact Us Work Camper Opportunities Terms & Conditions Welcome and thank you for choosing Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort & Campground (SRRRC) to be your vacation destination and home away from home. Our staff is here to help with anything you may need, just stop by the office,¬†and let us know. You agree to SRRRC adding your email to¬†our newsletter database. Your information will not be sold to any third party, and you can unsubscribe at any time. Our number one rule is to have fun,¬†however, to ensure everyone stays safe we do have resort rules listed below. Any violations of user rules could result in fines and or immediate departure from the park. We all just want to have safe and fun time. Resort Rules Guests and¬†visitors must register at the office. If you are going to reserve the same site for the following year, you must make your reservation during check-in. Parking passes are required for all vehicles and must be displayed in the windshield. Only 2 vehicles and 1 RV per site. No more than 6 people, including visitors per registered guest. Visitor parking for RV sites is located at the pool pavilion. Speed limit is 10mph¬†throughout the resort. Quiet hours are 11pm¬†‚Äì 8am. No loud music: if your neighbor can hear it, it is too loud. If you feel disturbed, please call 727.457.3925 or 386.294 . 3963 . Children under 16 years of age must be at their campsite or accompanied by an adult after 11:00pm. No unnecessary use of golf carts or ATVs after 11:00pm. Fireworks are not permitted at any time and firearms cannot be used at the resort. Golf cart operators must be at least 16 years old and have a valid driver‚Äôs license. All riders must always be seated. Proof of insurance is required for golf cart operations. There are no ATV trails at the resort. ATVs are permitted on roads only. Parents are responsible for the safety and conduct of their children. Parents will be held liable for all damages, acts of vandalism or injury caused by their children.¬†Children should be accompanied by an adult at the pool, river, and spring. SRRRC is not responsible for damages caused by other guests, their children or visitors and Acts of God. Fishing is allowed on the riverbank, boat ramp and spring run, (you must have a Florida Fishing License) and the catch & release pond (no license required). Fishing is not allowed in the spring. SRRRC is not responsible for lost or stolen items. Lost and Found is located at the office. If you find something, please turn it in at the office. If you lost something, please check with the office. No smoking of any kind in the lodge and outdoor dining deck. Security bands must be worn at all times. Rooms/Cabins/Houses Check in time is 4pm¬†and check out is 11am. Please do not use the room towels for the pool/spring. Complimentary pool towels are available in the office. No smoking of any kind in the rooms, cabins, and houses. There will be a $250 cleaning fee if smoking is detected after checking out. Well-mannered dogs are welcome! There is a $10 pet fee per day per pet¬†plus a refundable $100 hold. Charges will be assessed after checkout inspection. Grills and/or campfires are not allowed on any of the wooded porches. RV/Tent Sites Check in time is 2pm¬†and check out is 11am. Do not leave garbage at your site.¬† Dumpsters have been placed at the Entrance/Exit to the Rendezvous on East side of the Guard Shack.¬† Please Do Not place your personal trash in the public area cans by the pools or pavilions.¬† There will be a $50 fine if you use the public area cans for personal trash!¬† Please Do NOT place any large items such as mattresses, appliances, or furniture in or outside the dumpsters.¬† There will be a $150 fine if large items are left in or next to the dumpsters!¬† Containers for Recyclables will be marked and next to the dumpsters! Rubber donuts or plastic screw-in fittings are required on all sewer connections. Do not remove picnic tables and/or benches from sites. If you need extras, please contact the office. Pool Complex and Spring NO LIFEGUARD ON DUTY ‚Äì SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK. No¬†diving, no flipping and no running¬†in the pool complex¬†or the spring. Security bands must be worn at all times. Adults must accompany children under the age of 16 . Registered guests must be present at the pool or spring with their visitors. No glass allowed in the pool complex or spring. No drinks or smoking of any kind in the pool or spring. Ashtrays and beverages¬†are to remain on tables provided and not on the pools/hot tub decks. Campfires Campfires must¬†be attended to at all times. Campfires are only allowed in the fire rings provided at each site and throughout the resort. No trash burning. No dumping of charcoal on the ground or in fire rings. Dumping of charcoal, cigarette butts or garbage is subject to a $20 cleaning fee after checkout. Pets We love dogs but they must be leashed (6ft max), non-aggressive, no excessive barking, and¬†cleaned up after at all times.¬†THEY POOP ‚Äì YOU SCOOP! Pets of tent campers must always be attended to by a guest 16 years or older. Pets are not allowed to be left alone at tent sites unless they are crated. Charlie‚Äôs Dog Park is divided into 5 sections with agility courses and water stations. Poop bags are available at the entrance. Well behaved dogs are allowed in the lodge, spring and throughout the resort. Noisy or aggressive pets should be left at home. Pets are not allowed in the pool complex Rec Center or bathrooms. Dog washing station, with a hairdryer, is located at the pool laundry building. Please clean up when you are finished. Please do not use bathhouses to wash your pets. Discounts 10% discount on our daily RV rate to active, retired & veteran military, seniors 60 and over, and Good Sam members. Only ONE discount or coupon may be used per visit. Discounts are for daily rates ONLY and are NOT available on holiday weekends. We are a Passport America Campground. Members will receive the discount for their RV site when they present their card. Passport America discounts are for a maximum of 2 days and are not available on holiday weekends. Passport America memberships can be purchased at the office. Cancellation Policy Cancellations made 8 days or more prior to arrival date¬†will be charged $10 plus tax.¬† Cancellations made less than 8 days prior to arrival date will be charged the one-night deposit. For monthly reservations, cancellations made 30 days prior to check-in date will receive a refund minus a $10 plus tax¬†cancellation fee. Reservations cancelled within 30 days or less of arrival date will lose the $150 deposit.¬†No refunds for ‚Äúno shows‚Äù. Change Policy There will be a $10 plus tax¬†fee¬†for changes to reservations. Security Your safety is very important to us, so we have patrols of the campground and cameras placed around the campground for your safety. RV Security Tips for Your Next Big Adventure - Suwannee River Rendezvous Skip to Content Navigate Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort & Campground - 828 N.E. Primrose Rd, Mayo FL 32066 Phone : 386-294-2510 Email : frontdesk@suwanneeriverrendezvous.com BOOK NOW Home Site Map RV Resort Camping Lodging The A-Frame House The Chalet House Hill Top Rooms Lodge Rooms Log Cabins River Rooms The Spring House The Suite The Tree House Things to Do Coloring Pages Scavenger Hunt Pickle Ball Complex Activities Calendar Canoe and Kayak Rentals & Trips Park Activities Fishing & Hunting Special Events Out & About Cookin‚Äô Shack Information About Us Personal Pet Pens Area Springs Terms & Conditions The Suwannee River Convict Spring News Contact Us Work Camper Opportunities RV Security Tips for Your Next Big Adventure Posted March 27, 2018 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort At the Suwannee River Rendezvous, we welcome RV travelers from all over the country. Our smallest RV site is 40 by 80 feet, so we can accommodate RVs of all shapes and sizes. Visitors are welcome to park either on the original campground, or at the new Rendezvous resort, where guests can wake up to our beautiful pool complex and spa. But as every RV owner knows, it‚Äôs important to protect your vehicle against unwanted intruders when you‚Äôre on the road. Today we‚Äôll look at a few security tips to help you get started. Upgrade Your Locks An RV is more than just a mode of transportation; it‚Äôs also your home away from home. With this in mind, consider upgrading your RV‚Äôs standard locks with high-quality padlocks or cylinder locks that can‚Äôt be easily broken. It‚Äôs generally a good idea to add locks to your hitch and steering wheel, as well. That way, you can enjoy your trip without having to worry about whether or not your belongings are safe. Invest in Security Lights Motion-activated security lights are great theft deterrents at night. You may even use similar lights to protect your house when you‚Äôre not on the road. Modern LED security lights are inexpensive, energy efficient and easy to install. They‚Äôre also bright enough to scare off anyone who might think about trying to break into your RV under cover of darkness. Park Smarter With an RV, you should back into campsites to make it easy to get out, right? Well, not necessarily. Pulling forward into campsites can make it much harder for thieves to make a quick getaway with your vehicle. It may add a few minutes to your exit, but your RV‚Äôs security is worth it. Next time you‚Äôre traveling in Florida, be sure to visit us on the Suwannee River! Clever Ways to Keep Mosquitoes Away From your Campsite - Suwannee River Rendezvous Skip to Content Navigate Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort & Campground - 828 N.E. Primrose Rd, Mayo FL 32066 Phone : 386-294-2510 Email : frontdesk@suwanneeriverrendezvous.com BOOK NOW Home Site Map RV Resort Camping Lodging The A-Frame House The Chalet House Hill Top Rooms Lodge Rooms Log Cabins River Rooms The Spring House The Suite The Tree House Things to Do Coloring Pages Scavenger Hunt Pickle Ball Complex Activities Calendar Canoe and Kayak Rentals & Trips Park Activities Fishing & Hunting Special Events Out & About Cookin‚Äô Shack Information About Us Personal Pet Pens Area Springs Terms & Conditions The Suwannee River Convict Spring News Contact Us Work Camper Opportunities Clever Ways to Keep Mosquitoes Away From your Campsite Posted June 14, 2019 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort Mosquitoes are a fact of life outdoors. They can smell the carbon dioxide in human breath from over 100 feet away, so it‚Äôs no wonder they flock to campsites this time of year. However, there‚Äôs no need to let these pesky creatures ruin your outdoor fun with itchy bites. Here are a few clever ways to deter mosquitoes during your next camping trip. Burn sage. Mosquitoes hate the smell of sage, so if you add some to your campfire they‚Äôll stay away. As an added bonus, ticks dislike it too! The sage smell will linger on your skin and clothing after the fire burns out, giving you extended protection. Pack dryer sheets. Even if you‚Äôre not planning on doing any laundry, pack some dryer sheets on your next camping trip. Mosquitoes and bees will avoid them, so place them under tablecloths, near food and in your pockets. Sprinkle some mouthwash. Mint is another smell that mosquitoes hate. After using some mint-flavored mouthwash, sprinkle it around your campsite to keep them away. Light a candle. Not only do citronella candles add ambiance to your campsite; they also keep mosquitoes at bay! Best of all, a single candle can offer hours of protection against mosquitoes. Rub yourself with citrus peel. Mosquitoes aren‚Äôt very fond of citrus oils, either. After you peel an orange or lemon, rub your skin with the peel to deter mosquitoes. This only works with fresh peel, so do it right away. Now that you know how to keep your campsite mosquito-free, it‚Äôs time to book your next adventure! We‚Äôd love to have you come visit us at the Suwannee River Rendezvous campground and RV resort this summer. We had a shade shelter (extra $) whi... more We stayed here for a week and found it a lovely and unique mix of quaint, old school campground combined with a modern RV park. The ‚Äúlower‚Äù section is nearest to the river and mainly tent or smaller camper sites. The ‚Äúupper‚Äù section is standard full hookup sites, mix of pull through and back in. We had a shade shelter (extra $) which was nice. The sites were laid out well, some larger than others but overall no different than most RV parks. We do not have a pet but we saw they have a very large dog park including a small agility course. The heated pool was amazing, and that area along with the hot tub and smaller unheated ‚Äúconversation‚Äù pool definitely has more of a resort feel. The Laundry area was fine, though busy and could probably be bigger for the size of the park. The activities here arewhat sets it apart: Bingo, trivia, karaoke, show me the money, newlywed game, exercise classes, redneck bowling, kick ball pool and as others have noted the pigeon races and chicken poo bingo are a hoot! If you are lucky you might see Charlie Girl-the owners potbelly pig who often rooms freely! The staff was friendly and helpful. When you arrive at this park you just go directly to your site and then go check in with the office after you hook up and settle in. That was a great feature though the signage or instructions were not exactly clear - luckily another camper saw us pull in and gave us some direction. Quite a few seasonal residents and all were warm and welcoming. We have already booked another stay for a few weeks in the fall! Regarding the dust mentioned by another reviewer. Yes it is noticeable for those right against the dirt road. We were one row over and while we noticed with the windows open things got dusty it did not bother us on a day-to-day.  (Fifth Wheel) Overall Rating There's a fairly long dirt road going into the campground and then you just go directly to your site. Turns out my site was also right next to the dirt road. Despite a bunch of signs saying 10 MPH people fly up and down the road. Well after 8 nights my fifth wheel was really covered with dust as well as my truck. For your info - site... more There's a fairly long dirt road going into the campground and then you just go directly to your site. Turns out my site was also right next to the dirt road. Despite a bunch of signs saying 10 MPH people fly up and down the road. Well after 8 nights my fifth wheel was really covered with dust as well as my truck. For your info - sites 106 thru 117 are all along the dirt road. Next the owner needed to trim the trees at the sites, A branch actually punctured my roof material along the edge while backing in. He came by two days later and trimmed a bunch of trees, that didn't help me much then. All that aside, the facilities were nice (laundry, pool, propane fill, office, etc.) The sites had picnic table, fire ring, and some had a roof over the picnic table. The sites are a combo of sand and stone. So we kept dragging sand inside but that's not unusual. The office is not where the large campground is, it's actually down in the woods by the river so you'll to go down there for anything. The river was high so the spring, Convict Spring, was flooded out with brown water but there are other springs in the area that don't flood and are much larger. The cell service was weird, one minute it would be none or one bar then five minutes later it would be 3 or 4 bars. (Verizon and AT&T both). We put up our WeBoost and could usually stream with buffering waits. No Comments filed under: Benefits of Camping , Camp Lodging , Camping , Camping Activities , Suwannee River Activities , Suwannee RV Resort , Tent Camping Tags: Dogs , First Aid Kits , Fleas and Ticks , Pet-Friendly Campsites Tips for Planning a Winter RV Camping Trip Posted January 13, 2023 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort Although it might be tempting to spend the cold months of winter hibernating at home, an RV trip can offer a great way to beat the winter blues and refresh yourself with time in the great outdoors. Most modern RVs are well equipped to handle cold temperatures, but it‚Äôs still a good idea to take some extra precautions before you embark on a winter camping trip. Check out a few of our favorite tips for traveling in an RV this winter below! Check Seals Around Windows and Doors Before you leave, inspect all the windows, doors, storage compartments and access panels on your RV to make sure they are properly sealed with weather stripping and caulk. An RV can be a cozy shelter during winter camping trips, but only if it‚Äôs properly protected against the elements. The last thing you want is to spend your whole trip searching for the source of a draft that could have been sealed before you left. Pack Emergency Supplies In addition to packing your usual emergency supplies like a first aid kit and weather radio , it‚Äôs a good idea to bring some additional cold-weather accessories as well. No Comments filed under: Camping , Suwannee RV Resort Tags: First Aid Kits , RV camping , Solar Chargers , Weather Radios Stay Safe on the Suwannee River With These Helpful Tips Posted April 4, 2018 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort There‚Äôs no better way to explore the Suwannee River than by canoe or kayak. Don‚Äôt Drink and Paddle Stowing a few beers in your canoe might seem like a nice idea, but trust us: alcohol and boating don‚Äôt mix. Inebriation will make it much harder to react quickly if you get into a dangerous situation on the water. ¬†In fact, alcohol is the number one contributing factor in recreational boating deaths. Rather than drinking while you paddle, wait till you get back to shore to enjoy a well-earned beer and a hot meal. Always Wear Your Personal Flotation Device Keep your life jacket on at all times, even if you‚Äôre a strong swimmer. Not only will it keep you afloat in strong currents, it will also make you more visible to your fellow canoers and kayakers. This way, if your boat tips over, you can get back in sooner rather than later. Dress for the Weather Wet clothing can cause you to lose body heat at a rapid pace, making it possible to get hypothermia even in relatively warm weather. In general you should wear light, water-resistant layers, and avoid cotton garments whenever possible. Bring a Buddy It‚Äôs always best to paddle with at least one other person, especially if you don‚Äôt have a lot of boating experience. The more people you travel with, the easier it will be to spot potential hazards and help each other out in the event of an emergency. No Comments filed under: Benefits of Camping , Camping , Camping Activities , Camping Meals , Family Camping , Suwannee River Activities , Suwannee RV Resort , Tent Camping Tags: Camping Tips , Recycling , Trash Disposal , Water Bottles Learn How to Build a Great Campfire with These Helpful Tips Posted October 7, 2022 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort There‚Äôs nothing like sitting next to a roaring campfire underneath a starry sky, but do you know how to get the fire started? Learn how to build a great campfire with these helpful tips: First, gather your tinder‚Äîmaterial that will catch fire and burn fast. This includes dry grasses, leaves, bark and wood shavings. Many campers also like having firelighter cubes on hand. Make sure all the wood you‚Äôre using is dry. Wet wood is not only harder to burn, it‚Äôs also more prone to generating smoke and small bits of debris. There are three popular campfire designs to consider: a cone, a log cabin and a pyramid. You can familiarize yourself with these three options here and choose the one that works best for you. Using a match or lighter, light the tinder. Then, blow gently on the base of the fire to add oxygen, which will intensify the flame and help light the larger pieces of wood. Stay near your fire as it burns. Never leave a campfire unattended . As the fire burns, move embers toward the center so they‚Äôll be completely burned. Ideally, you should burn them until they become white ash. Eventually, it will be time to extinguish your fire. Pour water on it, stir the ashes and repeat as many times as needed. Before you leave the fire, make sure the remaining ashes are cool to the touch. No Comments filed under: Benefits of Camping , Camping , Camping Activities , Camping Board Games , Camping Card Games , Camping Games , Family Camping , River Lore , Suwannee River Activities , Suwannee RV Resort , Water Activities Prepare for Hot Weather Camping in Florida Posted March 25, 2022 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort It‚Äôs only March, but before too long that famous Florida heat will be returning to the Suwannee River. Hot, humid weather can make tent camping a little challenging during the peak months of summer, but it doesn‚Äôt have to keep you from having a good time. In fact, with a little care and preparation, you can camp comfortably and enjoy yourself even on the warmest days of the year! Here are some tips to help you stay cool: Stay Hydrated Of course, this is the most important thing to keep in mind on especially hot days. Drinking plenty of water will not only prevent you from getting dehydrated, but also help to regulate your body temperature so that you don‚Äôt overheat. Keep a bottle of water on hand at all times, and consider packing some refreshing snacks like cucumbers and watermelons for the trip as well. Stay Dry Circulation is key for keeping your tent cool overnight, but it can be problematic if you get surprised by a summer rainstorm. If your tent‚Äôs rain fly makes it feel hot and stuffy inside, create a canopy over your tent by tying a tarp to a couple of nearby trees instead. This will keep your tent dry without blocking air flow and impeding circulation. Dress Ligh t How hot you feel depends largely on what you‚Äôre wearing, and certain materials perform better in heat than others. In general, you should avoid clothes made of cotton. For shirts, consider a merino wool base layer that washes well and is light to wear. These days, you can also find active-wear pants that are soft, light and capable of wicking away excess moisture. Be sure to bring a good pair of waterproof shoes, too; if you‚Äôre sweaty, you don‚Äôt want your feet to be. Getting ready to plan this year‚Äôs summer camping getaway? We‚Äôd love to see you at Suwannee River Rendezvous . If you‚Äôre nervous about the heat, you can even stay in one of our air conditioned vacation homes ! Give us a call or contact us online today to learn more. At that time there were only a few buildings and the primitive campground area . Frank started cleaning the area and stabilizing all the buildings. In 2009 another 20 acres was purchased, which is now considered the upper area of the Rendezvous. In 2010, another seven acres were added to the property. Frank planned and constructed the Upper Rendezvous area which was completed in 2012 and added 136 RV sites as well as the dog park, barn and pigeon coop. The dog park has five sections, for both small and large dogs, with ample room to run. Frank began raising pigeons in 2012. The first pigeons purchased were homing pigeons which started the Pigeon Races that are still a fun, family favorite event on Saturday afternoons. Frank also purchased and started raising other pigeons, the Birmingham Roller. Birmingham Rollers are a very popular breed of domesticated pigeons that originated in Birmingham, England, where they were developed via selective breeding, for their ability to do rapid backward somersaults while flying. You can often see them flying around the Upper Rendezvous in the mornings and afternoons. These pigeons are used for our weekly Pigeon Races. There have always been chickens at the Rendezvous; however, Chicken Poo Bingo started in 2016. According to the Wall Street Journal, the concept of the game was invented in a New Orleans bar during the 1980s. Chicken Poo Bingo is exclusive to the Rendezvous here in the State of Florida. Grandma Susie‚Äôs Cookin‚Äô Shack has a varied menu and serves Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. You can take out, eat in our indoor or outdoor seating area. Another great feature here at the Rendezvous is the Suwannee River where you can plan a kayak or canoe trip here. We have a 6 mile trip and two 12 mile trips which include shuttle service. Shuttle service is also available for those who have their own equipment. All trips are a full day rental and include shuttle service, paddles, and life jackets. The Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort & Campground is home to Convict Spring. Convict Spring is a natural fresh water spring that feeds the Suwannee River. The spring is a ‚Äúcool‚Äù place to swim. It is also home to small fish and some turtles. Additions to the Rendezvous include the Catch and Release Pond, which is stocked and does not require a Florida Fishing License. Please respect the resident Peking ducks as the pond is their home. Our newest addition is the Outdoor Dining Deck which overlooks Convict Spring where you can see the high-level markers from floods throughout the years. Stay tuned for more information on our future Entertainment Complex. Our management team has over 50 years of resort experience. With that in mind, know that we are constantly working to provide you an experience that will provide a lifetime of memories. We invite you to join us on the beautiful Suwannee River . Let us know how we can improve your experience. Alligators are common in this area they can be dangerous should not be approached, frightened or fed. Please give them the respect they deserve. No Comments filed under: River Lore Reconnecting with Nature: Why Camping Benefits Your Mental and Physical Wellbeing Posted January 7, 2025 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort In our increasingly digital world, where screens dominate our daily lives and artificial lighting disrupts our natural rhythms, camping offers a powerful antidote. Better Sleep Through Natural Light One of camping‚Äôs most significant benefits comes from realigning our circadian rhythms. When we live by natural light rather than artificial illumination, our bodies better regulate sleep hormones like melatonin. Physical Activity Without Effort Unlike traditional exercise, camping makes physical activity feel effortless and enjoyable. Developing Resilience and Self-Reliance There‚Äôs something empowering about successfully managing life‚Äôs basics in an outdoor setting. Environmental Awareness and Appreciation Regular camping experiences foster a deeper connection with the natural world. This connection often leads to increased environmental awareness and a stronger commitment to conservation. When we spend time in nature, we better understand our place within the larger ecosystem and our responsibility to protect it. Practical Tips for Getting Started If you‚Äôre new to camping, start small. Try a well-maintained campground with basic facilities before venturing into more remote areas. Here‚Äôs what experienced RVers consider essential: Power Management Deep cycle batteries and a reliable generator for off-grid power Surge protector to safeguard electronics Extension cords and adapters for various hookup situations Water Systems Fresh water hose and pressure regulator Sewer hose kit with fittings and support Tank treatment chemicals and level monitors Safety Equipment Fire extinguisher and smoke/CO detectors Emergency roadside kit with flares First aid supplies and basic tools Leveling and Stabilization Leveling blocks and wheel chocks Stabilizing jacks Bubble level for proper setup Kitchen and Living Non-breakable dishware and cookware Manual can opener and basic utensils Space-saving storage containers Multi-purpose cleaning supplies Remember that your specific needs may vary based on your RV type, camping style, and destination. No Comments filed under: River Lore Don‚Äôt Leave Home Without These: Top 10 RV Trip Essentials Posted October 25, 2024 by Suwannee River Rendezvous Resort Top 10 RV Trip Essentials Planning an RV adventure? While the excitement of hitting the open road might have you eager to just hop in and drive, forgetting crucial items can quickly turn your dream vacation into a challenging experience. Here‚Äôs your must-pack list of the top 10 items that often slip travelers‚Äô minds but are absolute game-changers for RV living. 1. Surge Protector and Electrical Management System Nothing ruins an RV trip faster than fried electronics. Campground power can be unpredictable, and a quality surge protector isn‚Äôt just an accessory‚Äîit‚Äôs insurance for your valuable RV systems. Invest in a good 30 or 50 amp surge protector (matching your RV‚Äôs requirements) to protect against power surges, low voltage, and reverse polarity. 2. Sewer Hose Support System While everyone remembers the sewer hose, many forget the support system. These elevated supports create a proper slope for your sewer hose, ensuring efficient drainage and preventing the dreaded ‚Äúlow spot‚Äù that can trap waste. Trust me, this $20 investment will save you countless headaches. 3. Leveling Blocks and Wheel Chocks Perfect camping spots rarely come with perfectly level ground. A good set of leveling blocks will keep your RV stable and your appliances functioning properly. Wheel chocks are equally important‚Äîthey‚Äôre not just for parking on hills but are essential for safety whenever you‚Äôre parked. 4. Water Pressure Regulator Campground water pressure can vary wildly, sometimes exceeding levels safe for your RV‚Äôs plumbing. A water pressure regulator protects your pipes and connections from potentially damaging high-pressure water. Get one with a gauge so you can monitor the pressure levels. 5. Basic Tool Kit You don‚Äôt need to bring your entire garage, but a basic tool kit is essential. Include: Screwdrivers (flathead and Phillips) Adjustable wrench Pliers Duct tape WD-40 Zip ties Battery-powered drill 6. Emergency Road Kit Beyond your basic tool kit, pack: Tire pressure gauge Flashlights with extra batteries Jump starter or jumper cables Basic first aid supplies Emergency flares or reflective triangles Extra fuses 7. RV-Specific Toilet Paper and Tank Treatment Regular household toilet paper can wreak havoc on RV plumbing systems. Pack RV-specific toilet paper and don‚Äôt forget tank treatment chemicals to break down waste and control odors. Your nose (and your black water tank) will thank you later. 8. Weather Station A small weather station with temperature and humidity readings helps you monitor conditions inside and outside your RV. This is particularly important for protecting your RV from freezing temperatures or excessive heat, which can damage systems and make camping uncomfortable. 9. Backup Camera System If your RV doesn‚Äôt have one built-in, a wireless backup camera system is invaluable. It not only helps with parking but also provides peace of mind when changing lanes or maneuvering in tight spaces. Consider it an essential safety item, not a luxury. 10. Documentation Folder Create a folder containing: RV owner‚Äôs manual Appliance manuals Campground reservations RV insurance documents Vehicle registration Emergency contact numbers Campground membership cards Maps (yes, physical maps‚Äîdon‚Äôt rely solely on GPS) Final Thoughts While this list covers the often-forgotten essentials, remember that every RV trip is unique. Consider your specific needs, destination, and season when packing. It‚Äôs better to have these items and not need them than to need them and not have them. Happy camping! Pro Tip: Keep a running checklist of items you wish you had brought on previous trips. Your perfect packing list will evolve with experience.
